bibl.title: Letter fragment from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 28, 1900

div1.p: Reed describes the round of holiday parties, including one at the governor's palace, in Havana. He injects blood from the last yellow fever patient into a volunteer.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 28, 1900
div1.opener:
Columbia Barracks,
December 28th 1900,
Friday night.
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
If these
holiday gayeties don't
come to a cessation pretty
soon, I, for once, will be
completely used up! I feel
just as if I hadn't had
any sleep for a month.
Wednesday night the entire
garrison assembled at
Cap't. Waterman's for a
progressive Euchre party,
where we laughed, played
& ate good things till,
about midnight- Thurs-
day night (last night) we
all went down to attend
the Governor General's ball
and didn't get home till
1 o'clock, this morning- So that
to-night I am going to turn
in early and try to write
a few lines to my sweet
wifie in the early morn-
ing- I wish that you could
have been at the Palace,
last night, to have seen
the style and dress of the
Cuban ladies- They really
looked very pretty and
were dressed quite ele-
gantly. There must have
been a thousand people
there, making altogether
a very brilliant scene,
music for dancing was
furnished by a military
Band stationed in the
Park outside- The night
was just like summer wea-
ther- Mrs. Wood looked
quite pretty and asked
after you and precious little
daughter- I enjoyed watch-
ing the people as they passed
in and out, and particularly
the dancing of the Cubans.
Met a good many people
that I knew. To-day, the
morning was taken up
with a visit from half
a dozen doctors who wished
to see our last case of
fever and to visit our Camp.
Am glad to say that our
patient is doing very
well and promises to make
a good recovery. I shall
now begin on our paper
for the Pan-American
Congress, as I want to
have plenty of time in which
to write it- whether we
will have any more cases,
I can't say- we injected
some of the blood, taken from
our last case, under the
skin of one of the spaniards,
but whether it will do
any good, or rather bad, I
can't say yet- That was
done only two days ago.
well, precious heart, I am
so sleepy that I can't pos-
sibly write any more to-
night- I will go to bed
therefore and shall hope to
dream of my precious wifie
and dear little daughter. Boo! Boo!
